results.title: A Place to live: building in Maine
results.creator_credit: Lumen Bel Productions and Fred James
results.brief_description: This film shows how Pat and Patsy Hennim of Maine, U.S., adapt different building theories to build their own home in the woods, minimising on costs and maximising on living conditions. In turn they teach their ideas to a group of students.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Stuart Glover, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy
results.brief_description: Story of immigration and discussion of how newcomers look for houses, units or commission housing on offer in the city. Immigration officers help migrants get loans and settle in ‘suburbia’, the ideal for many migrants.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Claire Taplin and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Human struggle for shelter is as old as the struggle for food. The film examines the problems to be faced in the future of human settlements. How can they be solved in industrialised urban areas like New Zealand, and how different are the requirements of rural areas in a developing country like Indonesia. A significant feature of the film is the on-going comparison between Djkarta and Auckland - with some interesting changes 21 years on.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: National Social Welfare Assembly and Lee R. Bobker
results.brief_description: Stresses the need for old people to live in properly run homes for the aged. Suggests that in most cases living with their children - particularly when there are young grandchildren - will not work.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Documentary Film Productions and Irving Lerner
results.brief_description: Philadelphia was originally built as a city of fine homes and buildings, but just as the city and its industries grew, so did the areas of dilapidated housing. Life was a struggle for existence for those unfortunates in the abysmal slums. However with moves under way for urban renewal, new housing will arise where the ruins were. The life a mother leads with her young son and daughter in the slums with their hope for something better in the future is the story line.

results.title: A Place to live
results.brief_description: Lake Ellesmeer south of Christ Church is a popular breeding ground for many water birds. Every year some 5000 black swans nest on the lake’s shores. White swans multiply less prolifically. Mallard ducks, gulls, terns, wading birds including stilts and herons, all inhabit the Ellesmeer district. Canada geese fly down from the hills in December and January for their molting season. As more wet lands are drained these birds are in danger of losing their home.

results.title: A Place to land
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Ivern Hendrickson
results.brief_description: A review of the great occasions in aviation history in Australia, followed by a report on the planning, construction and opening of the new international air terminals at Sydney’s Kingsford-Smith Airport and Tullamarine, Victoria.
